dialogue.text: (Elias knocks on the ornate door of Lady Isabella's guest room. The late afternoon sun casts long shadows across the hallway. Tension is in the air.)
Lady Isabella? May I have a word?
Oh, Detective Elias. Of course. Please, come in.
(Elias steps into a refined room, tastefully decorated but cold. Isabella pours herself a cup of tea but doesn't offer one to Elias.)
I've heard from several people that you were speaking to someone during the party last night... someone wearing a gold mask.
Is that so? The party was full of masked strangers. I'm afraid I don't remember every face, Detective.
Lady Rosalind said you were seen conversing quite intently with this person. She said he didn't he didn't appear to be Lord Fairfax.
Oh? I suppose it could've been someone else. I didn't ask for names. We spoke briefly, nothing important.
But you accepted something from him, didn't you? A bouquet of roses.
Ah, yes. It was... unexpected. A gesture, perhaps. Nothing more. I have many admirers, Detective.
Interesting. Because the man you spoke with seemed very eager to avoid others. Even Lady Rosalind mentioned his rude behavior.
I suppose some guests do not feel comfortable conversing with everyone,, unlike the friendly Lady Rosalind. May I ask, Detective... what is this really about?
I'm piecing together the final moments of Lady Eleanor. She spoke with only a handful of people that night-- and after those conversations, her mood changed drastically. She was angry. Disturbed.
... Eleanor had a way of getting under people's skin. She was never afraid to speak her mind, no matter how cruel.
Did she ever speak your mind to you?
Are you accusing me of something, Detective?
... not yet. But your answers are... interesting. That'll be all for now, Lady Isabella. THank you for your time.
Of course. Anything for justice.
(Elias scans the hallway, the manor now unusually quiet. A sense of urgency creeps into his step as he searches for any sign of Sir Fairfax)
I wonder where Sir Fairfax could be...
Excuse me, Edith. Do you know where Sir Fairfax could be...
Pardon me, Sir. I do not know and the last time I saw him, he said he did not want to be interrupted and needed his time alone.
Alright, thank you for the information
(I better not be wasting my time. Maybe I can go interview Lady Rosalind first.)
(Outside the parlor, Elias hears hurried footsteps and muffled voices. Lady Rosalind paces nervously, clutching a glass of sherry.)
Where could Lady Rosalind be...
When will the murderer be exposed? I need to get out here before they find the next victim!
Perfect timing, may I talk to you for a moment?
Anything, Detective! I need all this panic to be over soon.
Were you wearing a silver mask at the party last night?
Err, yes... and why do you ask that?
According to what Edith said, you were one of the people who chatted with Lady Eleanor during the party.
Yes, but wait. Arre you suspecting me, Detective?
Are you out of your mind?! Lady Eleanor and I have known each other since we were children! Why would I enact such horrific action towards her?
... however, she was definitely not in a good mood the night before after talking to someone, and I could see anger in her eyes afterwards...
I went to get a drink for her, and when I returned she grew more furious after talking to someone in a gold mask!
Do you know who wore the gold mask?
I am not certain, but there some things I noticed.
What is it, my Lady?

I think there were two guests wearing gold masks last night. One was wearing a striking sapphire blue suit, which I believe was Lord Fairfax, and the other one was wearing a simple black suit, and looked a bit... older?
Are you certain about that, my Lady?

My eyes have never lied to me! Lord Fairfax was a gentleman the whole night, but when it came to the man in the black suit, I tried starting a conversation with but he dismissed me and seemed to be in a rush. How rude of him, now that I think of it.
I did see him talk with Lady Isabella though, even handing her a bouquet of roses which made it even stranger!
I see... Thank you for your time, my Lady.
Yes, let me know if you need me, Detective, I would do anything to get justice for Lady Eleanor.
